Introduction
Having already defined rcwa mappings and rcwa groups in the Preface, we will give a couple of basic definitions followed by a list of some elementary properties of the defined objects, several examples, a very brief statement of a few results and finally a few open questions in this chapter.
For everything not included in this manual (most theorems and lemmata, all proofs, ...) the reader is referred to the author's thesis .
We assume that on our underlying ring R we have defined a function which maps each element to some standard associate. For the rings treated in this package we have chosen the following:
\mathbb{Z}
The standard associate is the absolute value.
\mathbb{Z}_{(\pi)}
The standard associate of n is the largest product of non-invertible primes dividing n.
GF(q)[x]
We get our standard associate by dividing by the leading coefficient.
Whenever we write the lcm ... we always mean its standard associate. We proceed with the definitions concerning rcwa mappings.
Modulus
The Modulus of an rcwa mapping f is the standard associate of a multiplicatively smallest ring element m such that the restriction of f to any residue class (mod m) is affine. \rightarrow .
Multiplier
In the notation we used in the definition of an rcwa mapping in the Preface (), the multiplier is the lcm of the coefficients a_{r(m)} in the numerators. \rightarrow .
Divisor
In the notation we used in the definition of an rcwa mapping in the Preface (), the divisor is the lcm of the coefficients c_{r(m)} in the denominators. \rightarrow .
integral
An rcwa mapping is called integral if its divisor equals 1, thus if no proper divisions occur. Be careful not to confuse this with the term integral rcwa mapping for rcwa mappings of the integers; normally it should be rather clear what is meant. \rightarrow .
Prime Set
The set of prime divisors of the product of the modulus, the multiplier and the divisor of an rcwa mapping. \rightarrow .
tame
An rcwa mapping is called tame if the cyclic group it generates is tame (definition: see below). Tameness is a class invariant (this means that all conjugates of tame mappings are also tame). \rightarrow .
wild
An rcwa mapping is called wild if it is not tame.
determinant
We define the determinant of an affine mapping n \mapsto (an+b)/c whose source is a residue class r(m) by b/am, and extend this definition additively to determinants of rcwa mappings and those restrictions to unions of residue classes. Then, using the notation from the definition of an rcwa mapping in the Preface (), the determinant of an rcwa mapping is given by
(see LaTeX version of the manual).
\frac{1}{m} \left( \sum_{r(m) \in R/mR} \frac{b_{r(m)}}{a_{r(m)}} \right).
\rightarrow .
Now the definitions concerning rcwa groups.
rcwa representation
Modulus
The Modulus of an rcwa group is the lcm of the moduli of its elements in case such an lcm exists and 0 otherwise. \rightarrow .
tame
An rcwa group is called tame if its modulus is not equal to 0. \rightarrow .
wild
An rcwa group is called wild if it is not tame.
Rcwa Representation
An homomorphism from some group into the group RCWA(R) of all bijective rcwa mappings of the ring R.
integral
An rcwa group is called integral if all of its elements are. See also the warning given in the description of the corresponding property of rcwa mappings. \rightarrow .
Prime Set
The prime set of an rcwa group is the union of the prime sets of its elements.
Listing a few relations between the terms defined so far should not be left out in this context:
-
The divisor of an rcwa mapping divides its modulus. The modulus, multiplier resp. divisor of a product of rcwa mappings divides the product of the moduli, multipliers resp. divisors of the factors, and the prime set of a product of rcwa mappings is a subset of the union of the prime sets of the factors.
-
Inverting a bijective rcwa mapping interchanges multiplier and divisor. The product of the modulus and the multiplier of a bijective rcwa mapping is a multiple of the modulus of its inverse, which in turn is a multiple of the multiplier of the mapping we started with. The multiplier of an integral bijective rcwa mapping equals 1. Inversion leaves the prime set invariant.

How do rcwa mappings look like? -- For purposes of illustrating the above definitions we list a number of examples.
We have already mentioned the Collatz mapping, which is usually given in the following slightly more adequate form:
T: \ \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow \mathbb{Z}, \ \ n \ \longmapsto \ \begin{cases} \frac{n}{2} & \text{if} \ n \ \text{is even}, \\ \frac{3n+1}{2} & \text{otherwise}. \end{cases}
The modulus of this mapping is 2, its multiplier is 3 and its divisor is 2, thus its prime set is \{2,3\}. The mapping T is surjective but not injective, as it bijectively maps the residue class 0(2) onto \mathbb{Z} and the residue class 1(2) onto 2(3).
A bijective rcwa mapping of the integers, thus an element of RCWA(\mathbb{Z}), which has already been investigated by several people before is given by
a: \ \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow \mathbb{Z}, \ \ n \ \longmapsto \ \begin{cases} \frac{3n}{2} & \text{if} \ n \equiv 0 \ (2), \\ \frac{3n + 1}{4} & \text{if} \ n \equiv 1 \ (4), \\ \frac{3n - 1}{4} & \text{if} \ n \equiv 3 \ (4). \end{cases}
The reader may easily guess modulus, multiplier, divisor and prime set of this mapping himself -- it is however a good easy exercise for getting familiar with rcwa mappings to try to find its inverse by hand. The result can afterwards be checked using this package. It can be seen easily that the mapping a centralizes the involution n \mapsto -n. The permutation a has several finite cycles (find out which!), and as far as I know it is an unsolved problem whether the cycle containing 8 is really infinite. Finally try to guess whether a is tame or wild!
The next one is an example of an rcwa mapping of \mathbb{Z}_{(2)}:
f: \mathbb{Z}_{(2)} \ \longrightarrow \ \mathbb{Z}_{(2)}, \ \ n \ \longmapsto \ \begin{cases} \frac{1}{3}n - 7 & \text{if} \ n \equiv 0 \ (2), \\ 5n + \frac{1}{5} & \text{if} \ n \equiv 1 \ (2). \end{cases}
The reader may test his understanding of the definitions by trying to determine the multiplier and the divisor of this mapping and by trying to figure out whether it is surjective, injective or even bijective -- all of this should be quite easy. The mapping f is tame (why?).
As our last example for now we give a wild element of RCWA(GF(2)[x]):
r \in {\rm RCWA}({\rm GF}(2)[x]), \ \ P \ \longmapsto \ \begin{cases} \frac{(x^2 + x + 1)P }{x^2 + 1} & \text{if} \ P \equiv 0 \ (x^2 + 1), \\[1mm] \frac{(x^2 + x + 1)P + x}{x^2 + 1} & \text{if} \ P \equiv 1 \ (x^2 + 1), \\[1mm] \frac{(x^2 + x + 1)P + x^2}{x^2 + 1} & \text{if} \ P \equiv x \ (x^2 + 1), \\[1mm] \frac{(x^2 + x + 1)P + (x^2 + x)}{x^2 + 1} & \text{if} \ P \equiv x + 1 \ (x^2 + 1). \\ \end{cases}
The permutation r obviously fixes the degree of any polynomial, hence has only finite cycles. But there is an easy-to-check criterion which tells us that r is wild: its multiplier and divisor do not have the same prime divisors. Thus there cannot be an upper bound on the cycle lengths!
We proceed with a list briefly giving some results and remarks (in arbitrary order).
-
The group RCWA(R) acts highly transitive (i.e. k-fold transitive for any k) on R. It follows immediately that its centre is trivial, and from , Corollary 7.2A we know that any non-trivial normal subgroup must also act highly transitive on R.
-
A group can faithfully be represented as a tame rcwa group over the ring R if and only if it is isomorphic to a subgroup of the wreath product of the affine group of R with some large enough finite symmetric group.
-
The action of a tame group on the underlying ring R is imprimitive and there is a block system which consists of finitely many single residue classes, the so-called respected class partition. \rightarrow .
-
Any tame rcwa group is conjugate to an integral group provided that the underlying ring R has residue class rings of any finite cardinality. \rightarrow and .
-
Even in wild groups we can often factor elements into generators -- often in this context means something like if the element is a product of not more than 15 or 20 generators or inverses of generators -- of course this depends very much on the particular group and on the particular generators. Note that using the naive approach this would be far from being possible. \rightarrow .
-
The determinant induces an epimorphism from the group RCWA^+(\Z) of all class-wise order-preserving rcwa mappings of \Z onto (\Z,+). An immediate consequence is that this large subgroup of RCWA(\Z) is not simple. \rightarrow
-
Taking the set of all residue classes of R as a basis of a topology turns RCWA(R) into a group of homoeomorphisms. Such a topology has already been introduced on the integers by Harry Fürstenberg in for a topological proof of the infinitude of primes.
-
The group RCWA(R) acts transitive on the set of unions of finitely many residue classes distinct from the empty set and R itself, provided that R has a residue class ring of cardinality 2.
-
Assume that the ring R has a residue class ring of cardinality 2 and that S is a non-empty union of finitely many residue classes of R. Then the group RCWA(R) has an isomorphic subgroup which acts faithfully on the set S and fixes its complement. Images under the corresponding restriction monomorphisms are algorithmically easy to compute. \rightarrow and .
-
If k is coprime to the order of any torsion element of the group of units of R, the group RCWA(R) has only finitely many conjugacy classes of elements of order k -- otherwise it has infinitely many such conjugacy classes. In the former case the number of such classes can be computed easily. \rightarrow .
-
Suitable rings admit wild rcwa mappings having only finite cycles. Of course in these cases the set of cycle lengths cannot be bounded to the above. The existence of such mappings can be observed relatively easy for rings like GF(q)[x] (see above), but e.g. on \mathbb{Z}, constructing examples is more difficult. \rightarrow Section .
-
For better understanding given rcwa mappings as well as for constructing new ones with given properties, it is often helpful to associate directed graphs to them which reflect from which residue classes elements are mapped to which other residue classes -- we call these graphs transition graphs. \rightarrow .
-
There is no bijective rcwa mapping g such that the conjugate of the Collatz mapping under g maps all but finitely many positive integers to smaller ones. However, if the Collatz conjecture is true there must be some other permutation of the integers which serves this purpose.
We end this chapter by listing a few open problems (in arbitrary order).
-
Find out whether the groups RCWA(R) are simple or not. In case that they are not simple, determine a non-trivial normal subgroup and the structure of the factor group. Despite of the result concerning RCWA^+(\Z) I would consider this problem to be wide open, as the determinant mapping does not seem to have nice properties outside that large subgroup or for rings other than \Z. Do the groups RCWA(R) have non-trivial outer automorphisms?
-
What kind of structure can wild rcwa groups have? Only very little is currently known about this. E.g.: Does a free group of rank greater than 1 have a faithful rcwa representation? (almost certainly). Do the groups GL(n,\mathbb{Z}) have such a representation? (good question). Do all finitely presented groups have faithful rcwa representations? Are all finitely generated rcwa groups even finitely presented?
-
Is it possible that an rcwa group acts primitive but not highly transitive on one of its infinite orbits? There is some weak computational evidence suggesting a negative answer. \rightarrow and . Are point stabilizers of finitely generated rcwa groups always finitely generated, also?
-
Prove the Collatz conjecture (maybe this is the hardest one). The theory of residue class-wise affine mappings gives rise to nice and natural generalizations of this long-standing conjecture. For related functionality of this package see and . See also the examples given in Section , and .
